description: From Late Latin pericope, from Ancient Greek περικοπή (perikopḗ, “section”), from περι- (peri-, “across”) + κοπή (kopḗ, “cutting”), from κόπτω (kóptō, “I cut”).

entries.meaning: (rhetoric) A section of text forming a coherent thought, suitable for use in a speech.
A passage of Scripture to be read in public worship or a book containing such passages.
examples: The reader looked up the Sunday morning pericope.
The oldest known system of pericopes in the Western Church is ascribed to Jerome.
